repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
I think it's safe to enable this by default for 0.10 so everyone can appreciate our shiny syntax-highlighted code blocks.

**Question:** Do we want to provide an opt-out?

comment_data.body:
`lang = nil` is passed.
I think lang should be `vimdoc`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,3 +1,7 @@
+-- use treesitter over syntax (for highlighted code blocks)
+vim.treesitter.start()

@@ -1,3 +1,7 @@
+-- use treesitter over syntax (for highlighted code blocks)
+vim.treesitter.start()

comment_data.body:
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26347#issuecomment-1837508178

It does not work if the language is auto detected.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -1,3 +1,7 @@
+-- use treesitter over syntax (for highlighted code blocks)
+vim.treesitter.start()

comment_regular_data.body:
`oldtest` fails with

```
Found errors in Test_linebreak_list():
Caught exception in Test_linebreak_list(): Vim(runtime):E5113: Error while calling lua chunk: ../../../runtime
/lua/vim/treesitter/language.lua:98: no parser for 'vimdoc' language, see :help treesitter-parsers
stack traceback:    
[C]: in function 'error'        
../../../runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/language.lua:98: in function 'add'
../../../runtime/lua/vim/treesitter/languagetree.lua:113: in function 'new'     
../../../runtime/lua/vim/treesitter.lua:64: in function '_create_parser'      
../../../runtime/lua/vim/treesitter.lua:131: in function 'get_parser' 
../../../runtime/lua/vim/treesitter.lua:467: in function 'start'        
/Users/clason/build/neovim_fork/runtime/ftplugin/help.lua:2: in main chunk @ command line..script /Users/clason/build/neovim_fork/test/old/testdir/runtest.vim[541]..function RunTheTest[55]..Test_linebreak_list[4]..modelines[1717]..FileType Autocommands for "*"..function <SNR>10_LoadFTPlugin[20]..script /Users/clason/build/neovim_fork/runtime/ftplugin/help.lua
```
Not sure why it can't find the parser; commenting out `filetype plugin on` in the failing test makes it pass, but I don't like this.

May need to add the `build/lib/nvim` dir to the &rtp in runtest.vim, as that's where the parsers are built to.

As for why it works without `:filetype plugin on`, it's because the runner uses `-u NONE`, so all the filetype detection stuff is usually off.

Is there any way to disable it or opt-out by any chance? I'm not quite sure but I was wondering about the case where `vim.treesitter.start()` throws an error due to invalid/outdated parser and incompatible query files (which can conflict with the parsers compiled and managed by nvim-treesitter).

> Is there any way to disable it or opt-out by any chance? I'm not quite sure but I was wondering about the case where `vim.treesitter.start()` throws an error due to invalid/outdated parser and incompatible query files (which can conflict with the parsers compiled and managed by nvim-treesitter).

That's on nvim-treesitter (or your config); the same issue arises with any of the bundled parsers (in particular `query`, which is similarly enabled by default). There should be no error if downstream does things correctly, so no reason to guard against it. (Pessimization, and whatnot.)

To be clear: what you describe would be an issue no matter _how_ treesitter highlighting is enabled, so it's orthogonal to this PR.

> Do we want to provide an opt-out?

Isn't `vim.treesitter.stop()` the opt-out?

> Isn't `vim.treesitter.stop()` the opt-out?

Not quite; enabling and then disabling is not exactly the same as skipping enabling. (For example, you'd still get errors if `vim.treesitter.start()` doesn't work for some reason.) Not saying we _need_ to provide an opt-out, mind you.

> not exactly the same as skipping enabling.

How is that normally done for an ftplugin or syntax plugin?
It is not, really.

We can document the monkey-patch way to disable treesitter:

    vim.treesitter.start = function() end

That buys time until we have a better answer for how to disable syntax/ftplugin/treesitter.

No, that's the nuclear option that will disable _all_ treesitter. I shudder to think of the avalanche of confused issues this will trigger. Just to be clear: I'm talking about opt-out for _this and only this_ filetype default.

It can be adapted to be filetype-specific. The point is that we don't and won't introduce special-purpose flags for deprecated use-cases, instead document the monkey-patch approach. This should be the answer going forward, for all such cases.

```lua
vim.treesitter.start = (function(wrapped)
  return function(bufnr, lang)
    lang = lang or vim.fn.getbufvar(bufnr or '', '&filetype')
    if lang == 'help' then
      return
    end
    wrapped(bufnr, lang)
  end
end)(vim.treesitter.start)
```
What I'm hearing is that you will take these colors and you will like it. We're all-in on treesitter now.

> It can be adapted to be filetype-specific. The point is that we don't and won't introduce special-purpose flags for deprecated use-cases, instead document the monkey-patch approach. This should be the answer going forward, for all such cases.

Hi.  I have tested the code.  It does not work for help files.  For other filetypes are works.

`lang` is nil when help file.   Oh no.

```lua
vim.treesitter.start = (function(wrapped)
  return function(bufnr, lang)
    if lang == nil then
      return
    end
    wrapped(bufnr, lang)
  end
end)(vim.treesitter.start)
```

It works for me.

In my opinion, monkey patch is bad idea because sometime happens conflicts with other changes.
At least that's not what the official recommendation is.

> monkey patch is bad idea because sometime happens conflicts with other changes.

What other changes? 

> `lang` is nil when help file. Oh no.

I updated the code in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26347#issuecomment-1837508178 to also check 'filetype'.

I apologize for providing my opinion without reading the documents.
If `vim.treesitter.start()` is dedicated for highlighting purposes, then indeed, there is no need to worry about conflicts.

> I updated the code in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/26347#issuecomment-1837508178 to also check 'filetype'.

Thank you.  It works.

> If vim.treesitter.start() is dedicated for highlighting purposes, then indeed, there is no need to worry about conflicts.

The function name seems confused though.
No, that is not planned. The goal is to make treesitter a safe and, all things considered, better choice. (This includes better error handling.)

@clason 
thanks.
I understand your premise about the incompleteness of treesitter, which can be improved in the future.
However, the cost of treesitter will never be zero, just as the old syntax is.
I would appreciate it if you could provide users with a straightforward way to eliminate this, if possible.
I hear you, but the answer is still no. There should be no (reasonable) reason not to have this enabled, so maintaining such an option is wasted effort that is better spent elsewhere.

@clason 
Isn't it REASONABLE that users who don't use treesitter don't want to pay that cost?

No, because "that cost" is not well defined. You're not complaining about the legacy regex syntax engine being enabled by default, and that one is not "free" either. So why should treesitter be different?

@clason 
Sure, I agree that "that cost" is not well defined.
If I could define well it, I may discuss about it again (in another issue).

However, we can disable the legacy regex syntax engine by straight way (`:syntax off`).
I don't think it is such an outlandish request to provide a method that is as simple as it is.

But `vim.treesitter.stop()` already exists. That's the exact analogue of `:syntax off`. (Well, technically, `au FileType * lua vim.treesitter.stop()`.)

Or, if you want the nuclear option (which has the exact same effect as `:syntax off`), `vim.treesitter.start = function() end`. All these are easy enough for what should be an extremely uncommon scenario.

I see.
I agree that "last resort" it would be an easy solution for the maintainer, but whether it is a "straight" way or not is subjective, so I will defer to your wishes for once.

Thanks for answering so many of my questions.

repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

title: feat(treesitter): highlight help files by default
